Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Story: I stood in the kitchen, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my client’s voice crackle through the line. She needed clarification on a line item from her invoice, and I could hear the urgency in her tone. My laptop was open on the counter, spreadsheets glowing with numbers that needed my attention. At the same time, the clatter of dishes and the hum of the vacuum from the living room reminded me of the other expectation waiting for me. My spouse called out, asking if I could help fold the laundry and tidy up the guest room before his relatives arrived in a few hours. The house was a whirlwind of activity, and every surface needed to be spotless. I felt the pressure mounting—my client expected a prompt, professional response, but my partner needed me to share the load at home. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to my work and the commitment to my marriage, both demanding my full attention at the very same moment.
